div.p: Greetings. For your friendly disposition towards me, which you wished to declare by the book sent to me, I give you immense thanks, my dear Bullinger, and although at this time I am extremely busy with completing books of greater importance, I will nevertheless make an effort, as much as possible, to gratify you in this matter either at our home or through another. Recently, I received from Augsburg two rather long letters written in Latin on the same business, which a certain friend of ours, Heinzelius, also sent to me and thinks it worthwhile to publish. Perhaps I will join them to your little book, so that we may pour out the whole broth at once.
Farewell, my dear Bullinger, and pray to the Lord for us. Basel, August 9, 1550.
Your Johannes Oporinus from the heart.

I was about to write the same to Lord Pietro Paolo Vergerio; but since there was no leisure, I wish these little letters to be shared with him through you. Also, greet him in my name as courteously as possible.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, his esteemed friend. Zürich.
To the most excellent and learned man, Lord Heinrich Bullinger, his esteemed friend. Zürich.
